Level.name: Topic Development in Terms of Purpose and Focus (TOD)
Level.subject: English

Statement.name: Delete material because it is obviously irrelevant in terms of the topic of the essay
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Delete material because it is obviously irrelevant in terms of the focus of the essay
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Identify the purpose of a word or phrase when the purpose is simple (e.g., identifying a person, defining a basic term, using common descriptive adjectives)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine whether a simple essay has met a straightforward goal
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine relevance of material in terms of the focus of the essay
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Identify the purpose of a word or phrase when the purpose is straightforward (e.g., describing a person, giving examples)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use a word, phrase, or sentence to accomplish a straightforward purpose (e.g., conveying a feeling or attitude)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine relevance of material in terms of the focus of the paragraph
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Identify the purpose of a word, phrase, or sentence when the purpose is fairly straightforward (e.g., identifying traits, giving reasons, explaining motivations)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine whether an essay has met a specified goal
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use a word, phrase, or sentence to accomplish a fairly straightforward purpose (e.g., sharpening an essay's focus, illustrating a given statement)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine relevance when considering material that is plausible but potentially irrelevant at a given point in the essay
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Identify the purpose of a word, phrase, or sentence when the purpose is subtle (e.g., supporting a later point, establishing tone) or when the best decision is to delete the text in question
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use a word, phrase, or sentence to accomplish a subtle purpose (e.g., adding emphasis or supporting detail, expressing meaning through connotation)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Identify the purpose of a word, phrase, or sentence when the purpose is complex (e.g., anticipating a reader's need for background information) or requires a thorough understanding of the paragraph and essay
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine whether a complex essay has met a specified goal
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use a word, phrase, or sentence to accomplish a complex purpose, often in terms of the focus of the essay
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine the need for transition words or phrases to establish time relationships in simple narrative essays (e.g., then, this time)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine the most logical place for a sentence in a paragraph
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Provide a simple conclusion to a paragraph or essay (e.g., expressing one of the essay's main ideas)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine the need for transition words or phrases to establish straightforward logical relationships (e.g., first, afterward, in response)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine the most logical place for a sentence in a straightforward essay
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Provide an introduction to a straightforward paragraph
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Provide a straightforward conclusion to a paragraph or essay (e.g., summarizing an essay's main idea or ideas)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Rearrange the sentences in a straightforward paragraph for the sake of logic
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine the need for transition words or phrases to establish subtle logical relationships within and between sentences (e.g., therefore, however, in addition)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Provide a fairly straightforward introduction or conclusion to or transition within a paragraph or essay (e.g., supporting or emphasizing an essay's main idea)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Rearrange the sentences in a fairly straightforward paragraph for the sake of logic
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine the best place to divide a paragraph to meet a particular rhetorical goal
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Rearrange the paragraphs in an essay for the sake of logic
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine the need for transition words or phrases to establish subtle logical relationships within and between paragraphs
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine the most logical place for a sentence in a fairly complex essay
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Provide a subtle introduction or conclusion to or transition within a paragraph or essay (e.g., echoing an essay's theme or restating the main argument)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Rearrange the sentences in a fairly complex paragraph for the sake of logic and coherence
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine the need for transition words or phrases, basing decisions on a thorough understanding of the paragraph and essay
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Provide a sophisticated introduction or conclusion to or transition within a paragraph or essay, basing decisions on a thorough understanding of the paragraph and essay (e.g., linking the conclusion to one of the essay's main images)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Revise vague, clumsy, and confusing writing that creates obvious logic problems
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Delete obviously redundant and wordy material
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Revise expressions that deviate markedly from the style and tone of the essay
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Delete redundant and wordy material when the problem is contained within a single phrase (e.g., Õalarmingly startled, started by reaching the point of beginningÒ)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Revise expressions that deviate from the style and tone of the essay
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine the need for conjunctions to create straightforward logical links between clauses
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use the word or phrase most appropriate in terms of the content of the sentence when the vocabulary is relatively common
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Revise vague, clumsy, and confusing writing
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Delete redundant and wordy material when the meaning of the entire sentence must be considered
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Revise expressions that deviate in subtle ways from the style and tone of the essay
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine the need for conjunctions to create logical links between clauses
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use the word or phrase most appropriate in terms of the content of the sentence when the vocabulary is uncommon
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Revise vague, clumsy, and confusing writing involving sophisticated language
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Delete redundant and wordy material that involves fairly sophisticated language (e.g., "the outlook of an aesthetic viewpoint") or that sounds acceptable as conversational English
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine the need for conjunctions to create subtle logical links between clauses
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use the word or phrase most appropriate in terms of the content of the sentence when the vocabulary is fairly sophisticated
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Delete redundant and wordy material that involves sophisticated language or complex concepts or where the material is redundant in terms of the paragraph or essay as a whole
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use the word or phrase most appropriate in terms of the content of the sentence when the vocabulary is sophisticated
Statement.subject: English

Level.name: Conventions of Standard English Grammar, Usage, and Punctuation (GUP)
Level.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine the need for punctuation or conjunctions to join simple clauses
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb tense between simple clauses in a sentence or between simple adjoining sentences
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine the need for punctuation or conjunctions to correct awkward-sounding fragments and fused sentences as well as obviously faulty subordination and coordination of clauses
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb tense and voice when the meaning of the entire sentence must be considered
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Recognize and correct marked disturbances in sentence structure (e.g., faulty placement of adjectives, participial phrase fragments, missing or incorrect relative pronouns, dangling or misplaced modifiers, lack of parallelism within a simple series of verbs)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Recognize and correct disturbances in sentence structure (e.g., faulty placement of phrases, faulty coordination and subordination of clauses, lack of parallelism within a simple series of phrases)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Maintain consistent and logical verb tense and pronoun person on the basis of the preceding clause or sentence
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Recognize and correct subtle disturbances in sentence structure (e.g., danglers where the intended meaning is clear but the sentence is ungrammatical, faulty subordination and coordination of clauses in long or involved sentences)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Maintain consistent and logical verb tense and voice and pronoun person on the basis of the paragraph or essay as a whole
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Recognize and correct very subtle disturbances in sentence structure (e.g., weak conjunctions between independent clauses, run-ons that would be acceptable in conversational English, lack of parallelism within a complex series of phrases or clauses)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Form the past tense and past participle of irregular but commonly used verbs
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Form comparative and superlative adjectives
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Determine whether an adjective form or an adverb form is called for in a given situation
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Ensure straightforward subject-verb agreement
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Ensure straightforward pronoun-antecedent agreement
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use idiomatically appropriate prepositions in simple contexts
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use the appropriate word in frequently confused pairs (e.g., there and their, past and passed, led and lead)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use the correct comparative or superlative adjective or adverb form depending on context (e.g., "He is the oldest of my three brothers")
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Ensure subject-verb agreement when there is some text between the subject and verb
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use idiomatically appropriate prepositions, especially in combination with verbs (e.g., long for, appeal to)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Recognize and correct expressions that deviate from idiomatic English
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Form simple and compound verb tenses, both regular and irregular, including forming verbs by using have rather than of (e.g., would have gone, not would of gone)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Ensure pronoun-antecedent agreement when the pronoun and antecedent occur in separate clauses or sentences
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Recognize and correct vague and ambiguous pronouns
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Ensure subject-verb agreement in some challenging situations (e.g., when the subject-verb order is inverted or when the subject is an indefinite pronoun)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Correctly use reflexive pronouns, the possessive pronouns its and your, and the relative pronouns who and whom
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use the appropriate word in less-common confused pairs (e.g., allude and elude)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Ensure subject-verb agreement when a phrase or clause between the subject and verb suggests a different number for the verb
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use idiomatically and contextually appropriate prepositions in combination with verbs in situations involving sophisticated language or complex concepts
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Delete commas that create basic sense problems (e.g., between verb and direct object)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Delete commas that markedly disturb sentence flow (e.g., between modifier and modified element)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use appropriate punctuation in straightforward situations (e.g., simple items in a series)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Delete commas when an incorrect understanding of the sentence suggests a pause that should be punctuated (e.g., between verb and direct object clause)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Delete apostrophes used incorrectly to form plural nouns
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use commas to avoid obvious ambiguity (e.g., to set off a long introductory element from the rest of the sentence when a misreading is possible)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use commas to set off simple parenthetical elements
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Delete commas in long or involved sentences when an incorrect understanding of the sentence suggests a pause that should be punctuated (e.g., between the elements of a compound subject or compound verb joined by and)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Recognize and correct inappropriate uses of colons and semicolons
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use punctuation to set off complex parenthetical elements
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use apostrophes to form simple possessive nouns
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use commas to avoid ambiguity when the syntax or language is sophisticated (e.g., to set off a complex series of items)
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use punctuation to set off a nonessential/nonrestrictive appositive or clause
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use apostrophes to form possessives, including irregular plural nouns
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use a semicolon to link closely related independent clauses
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Delete punctuation around essential/restrictive appositives or clauses
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Use a colon to introduce an example or an elaboration
Statement.subject: English

Statement.name: Show a little understanding of the persuasive purpose of the task but neglect to take or to maintain a position on the issue in the prompt
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Generate reasons for a position that are irrelevant or unclear
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Show a basic understanding of the persuasive purpose of the task by taking a position on the issue in the prompt
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Generate reasons for a position that are vague or simplistic; show a little recognition of the complexity of the issue in the prompt by briefly noting implications and/or complications of the issue, and/or briefly or unclearly responding to counterarguments to the writer's position
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Show clear understanding of the persuasive purpose of the task by taking a position on the issue in the prompt and offering some context for discussion
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Generate reasons for a position that are relevant and clear; show some recognition of the complexity of the issue in the prompt by acknowledging implications and/or complications of the issue, and/or providing some response to counterarguments to the writer's position
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Show strong understanding of the persuasive purpose of the task by taking a position on the specific issue in the prompt and offering a broad context for discussion
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Generate thoughtful reasons for a position; show recognition of the complexity of the issue in the prompt by partially evaluating implications and/or complications of the issue, and/or anticipating and responding to counterarguments to the writer's position
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Show advanced understanding of the persuasive purpose of the task by taking a position on the specific issue in the prompt and offering a critical context for discussion
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Generate insightful reasons for a position; show understanding of the complexity of the issue in the prompt by examining different perspectives, and/or evaluating implications and/or complications of the issue, and/or anticipating and fully responding to counterarguments to the writer's position
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Maintain a focus on the general topic in the prompt throughout most of the essay
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Maintain a focus on the general topic in the prompt throughout the essay
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Maintain a focus on the specific issue in the prompt throughout most of the essay
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Present a thesis that establishes focus on the topic
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Maintain a focus on discussing the specific issue in the prompt throughout the essay
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Present a thesis that establishes a focus on the writer's position on the issue
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Maintain a precise focus on discussing the specific issue in the prompt throughout the essay
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Present a critical thesis that clearly establishes the focus on the writer's position on the issue
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Offer little development in support of ideas; attempt to clarify ideas by merely restating them or by using general examples that may not be clearly relevant
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Show little or no movement between general and specific ideas and examples
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Offer limited development in support of ideas; clarify ideas somewhat with vague explanation and the use of general examples
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Show little movement between general and specific ideas and examples
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Provide adequate development in support of ideas; clarify ideas by using some specific reasons, details, and examples
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Show some movement between general and specific ideas and examples
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Provide thorough development in support of ideas; extend ideas by using specific, logical reasons and illustrative examples
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Show clear movement between general and specific ideas and examples
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Provide ample development in support of ideas; substantiate ideas with precise use of specific, logical reasons and illustrative examples
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Show effective movement between general and specific ideas and examples
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Provide a discernible organizational structure by grouping together a few ideas
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Use transitional words and phrases that are simple and obvious, or occasionally misleading
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Present a minimal introduction and conclusion
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Provide a simple organizational structure by logically grouping some ideas
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Use simple and obvious transitional words and phrases
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Present an underdeveloped introduction and conclusion
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Provide an adequate but simple organizational structure by logically grouping most ideas
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Use some appropriate transitional words and phrases
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Present a somewhat developed introduction and conclusion
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Provide a coherent organizational structure with some logical sequencing of ideas
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Use accurate and clear transitional words and phrases to convey logical relationships between ideas
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Present a generally well-developed introduction and conclusion
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Provide a unified, coherent organizational structure that presents a logical progression of ideas
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Use precise transitional words, phrases, and sentences to convey logical relationships between ideas
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Present a well-developed introduction that effectively frames the prompt's issue and writer's argument; present a well-developed conclusion that extends the essay's ideas
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Show limited control of language by: correctly employing some of the conventions of standard English grammar, usage, and mechanics, but with distracting errors that sometimes significantly impede understanding; choosing words that are simplistic or vague; using only simple sentence structure
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Show a basic control of language by correctly employing some of the conventions of standard English grammar, usage, and mechanics, but with distracting errors that sometimes impede understanding choosing words that are simple but generally appropriate using a little sentence variety
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Show adequate use of language to communicate by correctly employing many of the conventions of standard English grammar, usage, and mechanics, but with some distracting errors that may occasionally impede understanding choosing words that are appropriate using some varied kinds of sentence structures to vary pace
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Show competent use of language to communicate ideas by correctly employing most conventions of standard English grammar, usage, and mechanics, with a few distracting errors but none that impede understanding generally choosing words that are precise and varied using several kinds of sentence structures to vary pace and to support meaning
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Show effective use of language to communicate ideas clearly by correctly employing most conventions of standard English grammar, usage, and mechanics, with just a few, if any, errors consistently choosing words that are precise and varied; using a variety of kinds of sentence structures to vary pace and to support meaning
Statement.subject: Writing

Statement.name: Locate basic facts (e.g., names, dates, events) clearly stated in a passage
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Draw simple logical conclusions about the main characters in somewhat challenging literary narratives
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Locate simple details at the sentence and paragraph level in somewhat challenging passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Draw simple logical conclusions in somewhat challenging passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Locate important details in somewhat challenging passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Draw logical conclusions in somewhat challenging passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Paraphrase some statements as they are used in somewhat challenging passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Locate and interpret minor or subtly stated details in somewhat challenging passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Draw subtle logical conclusions in somewhat challenging passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Draw logical conclusions in more challenging passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Paraphrase some statements as they are used in more challenging passages

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Locate and interpret minor or subtly stated details in complex passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Locate important details in highly complex passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Draw logical conclusions in complex passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Draw simple logical conclusions in highly complex passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Draw complex or subtle logical conclusions, often by synthesizing information from different portions of the passage
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Paraphrase statements as they are used in complex passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Identify the topic of passages and distinguish the topic from the central idea or theme
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Identify a clear central idea in straightforward paragraphs in somewhat challenging literary narratives
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Infer a central idea in straightforward paragraphs in somewhat challenging literary narratives
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Identify a clear central idea or theme in somewhat challenging passages or their paragraphs
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Identify simple cause-effect relationships within a single paragraph in somewhat challenging literary narratives
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Interpret basic figurative language as it is used in a passage
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Analyze how the choice of a specific word or phrase shapes meaning or tone in somewhat challenging passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Interpret words and phrases in a passage that makes extensive use of figurative, general academic, domain-specific, or otherwise difficult language
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Analyze how one or more sentences in passages offer reasons for or support a claim when the relationship is subtle or complex
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Identify or infer a central claim in complex passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Identify a clear central claim in highly complex passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Make simple comparisons between two passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Make straightforward comparisons between two passages
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Draw logical conclusions using information from two literary narratives
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Draw logical conclusions using information from two informational texts
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Draw logical conclusions using information from multiple portions of two literary narratives
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Draw logical conclusions using information from multiple portions of two informational texts
Statement.subject: Reading

Statement.name: Select one piece of data from a simple data presentation (e.g., a simple food web diagram)
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Identify basic features of a table, graph, or diagram (e.g., units of measurement)
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Find basic information in text that describes a simple data presentation
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Select two or more pieces of data from a simple data presentation
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Understand basic scientific terminology
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Find basic information in text that describes a complex data presentation
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine how the values of variables change as the value of another variable changes in a simple data presentation
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Select data from a complex data presentation (e.g., a phase diagram)
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Compare or combine data from a simple data presentation (e.g., order or sum data from a table)
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Translate information into a table, graph, or diagram
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Perform a simple interpolation or simple extrapolation using data in a table or graph
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Compare or combine data from two or more simple data presentations (e.g., categorize data from a table using a scale from another table)
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Compare or combine data from a complex data presentation
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine how the values of variables change as the value of another variable changes in a complex data presentation
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine and/or use a simple (e.g., linear) mathematical relationship that exists between data
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Analyze presented information when given new, simple information
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Compare or combine data from a simple data presentation with data from a complex data presentation
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine and/or use a complex (e.g., nonlinear) mathematical relationship that exists between data
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Perform a complex interpolation or complex extrapolation using data in a table or graph
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Compare or combine data from two or more complex data presentations
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Analyze presented information when given new, complex information
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Find basic information in text that describes a simple experiment
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Understand the tools and functions of tools used in a simple experiment
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Understand the methods used in a simple experiment
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Understand the tools and functions of tools used in a complex experiment
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Find basic information in text that describes a complex experiment
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Understand a simple experimental design
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Understand the methods used in a complex experiment
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Identify a control in an experiment
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Identify similarities and differences between experiments
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine which experiments utilized a given tool, method, or aspect of design
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Understand a complex experimental design
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Predict the results of an additional trial or measurement in an experiment
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine the experimental conditions that would produce specified results
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine the hypothesis for an experiment
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine an alternate method for testing a hypothesis
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Understand precision and accuracy issues
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Predict the effects of modifying the design or methods of an experiment
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine which additional trial or experiment could be performed to enhance or evaluate experimental results
Statement.subject: Science

Level.name: Evaluation of Models, Inferences, and Experimental Results (EMI)
Level.subject: Science

Statement.name: Find basic information in a model (conceptual)
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Identify implications in a model
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine which models present certain basic information
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine which simple hypothesis, prediction, or conclusion is, or is not, consistent with a data presentation, model, or piece of information in text
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Identify key assumptions in a model
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine which models imply certain information
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Identify similarities and differences between models
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine which simple hypothesis, prediction, or conclusion is, or is not, consistent with data presentations, models, and/or pieces of information in text
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine whether presented information, or new information, supports or contradicts a simple hypothesis or conclusion, and why
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Identify the strengths and weaknesses of models
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine which models are supported or weakened by new information
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine which experimental results or models support or contradict a hypothesis, prediction, or conclusion
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine which complex hypothesis, prediction, or conclusion is, or is not, consistent with a data presentation, model, or piece of information in text
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine whether presented information, or new information, supports or weakens a model, and why
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Use new information to make a prediction based on a model
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine which complex hypothesis, prediction, or conclusion is, or is not, consistent with data presentations, models, and/or pieces of information in text
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Determine whether presented information, or new information, supports or contradicts a complex hypothesis or conclusion, and why
Statement.subject: Science

Statement.name: Perform one-operation computation with whole numbers and decimals
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Recognize equivalent fractions and fractions in lowest terms
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Locate positive rational numbers (expressed as whole numbers, fractions, decimals, and mixed numbers) on the number line
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Recognize one-digit factors of a number
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Identify a digit's place value
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Locate rational numbers on the number line
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Exhibit knowledge of elementary number concepts such as rounding, the ordering of decimals, pattern identification, primes, and greatest common factor
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Write positive powers of 10 by using exponents
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Comprehend the concept of length on the number line, and find the distance between two points
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Understand absolute value in terms of distance
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Find the distance in the coordinate plane between two points with the same x-coordinate or y-coordinate
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Add two matrices that have whole number entries
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Order fractions
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Find and use the least common multiple
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Work with numerical factors
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Exhibit some knowledge of the complex numbers
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Add and subtract matrices that have integer entries
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Apply number properties involving prime factorization
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Apply number properties involving even/odd numbers and factors/multiples
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Apply number properties involving positive/negative numbers
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Apply the facts that π is irrational and that the square root of an integer is rational only if that integer is a perfect square
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Apply properties of rational exponents
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Multiply two complex numbers
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Use relations involving addition, subtraction, and scalar multiplication of vectors and of matrices
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Analyze and draw conclusions based on number concepts
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Apply properties of rational numbers and the rational number system
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Apply properties of real numbers and the real number system, including properties of irrational numbers
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Apply properties of complex numbers and the complex number system
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Multiply matrices
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Apply properties of matrices and properties of matrices as a number system
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Calculate the average of a list of positive whole numbers
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Extract one relevant number from a basic table or chart, and use it in a single computation
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Calculate the average of a list of numbers
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Calculate the average given the number of data values and the sum of the data values
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Read basic tables and charts
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Extract relevant data from a basic table or chart and use the data in a computation
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Use the relationship between the probability of an event and the probability of its complement
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Calculate the missing data value given the average and all data values but one
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Translate from one representation of data to another (e.g., a bar graph to a circle graph)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Determine the probability of a simple event
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Describe events as combinations of other events (e.g., using and, or, and not)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Exhibit knowledge of simple counting techniques
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Calculate the average given the frequency counts of all the data values
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Manipulate data from tables and charts
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Compute straightforward probabilities for common situations
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Use Venn diagrams in counting
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Recognize that when data summaries are reported in the real world, results are often rounded and must be interpreted as having appropriate precision
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Recognize that when a statistical model is used, model values typically differ from actual values
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Calculate or use a weighted average
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Interpret and use information from tables and charts, including two-way frequency tables
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Apply counting techniques
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Compute a probability when the event and/or sample space are not given or obvious
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Recognize the concepts of conditional and joint probability expressed in real-world contexts
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Recognize the concept of independence expressed in real-world contexts
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Distinguish between mean, median, and mode for a list of numbers
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Analyze and draw conclusions based on information from tables and charts, including two-way frequency tables
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Understand the role of randomization in surveys, experiments, and observational studies
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Exhibit knowledge of conditional and joint probability
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Recognize that part of the power of statistical modeling comes from looking at regularity in the differences between actual values and model values
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Estimate the length of a line segment based on other lengths in a geometric figure
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Calculate the length of a line segment based on the lengths of other line segments that go in the same direction (e.g., overlapping line segments and parallel sides of polygons with only right angles)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Perform common conversions of money and of length, weight, mass, and time within a measurement system (e.g., dollars to dimes, inches to feet, and hours to minutes)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Exhibit some knowledge of the angles associated with parallel lines
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Compute the perimeter of polygons when all side lengths are given
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Compute the area of rectangles when whole number dimensions are given
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Locate points in the first quadrant
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Use properties of parallel lines to find the measure of an angle
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Exhibit knowledge of basic angle properties and special sums of angle measures (e.g., 90º, 180º, and 360º)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Compute the area and perimeter of triangles and rectangles in simple problems
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Find the length of the hypotenuse of a right triangle when only very simple computation is involved (e.g., 3-4-5 and 6-8-10 triangles)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Use geometric formulas when all necessary information is given
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Locate points in the coordinate plane
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Translate points up, down, left, and right in the coordinate plane
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Use several angle properties to find an unknown angle measure
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Count the number of lines of symmetry of a geometric figure
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Use symmetry of isosceles triangles to find unknown side lengths or angle measures
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Recognize that real-world measurements are typically imprecise and that an appropriate level of precision is related to the measuring device and procedure
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Compute the perimeter of simple composite geometric figures with unknown side lengths
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Compute the area of triangles and rectangles when one or more additional simple steps are required
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Compute the area and circumference of circles after identifying necessary information
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Given the length of two sides of a right triangle, find the third when the lengths are Pythagorean triples
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Express the sine, cosine, and tangent of an angle in a right triangle as a ratio of given side lengths
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Determine the slope of a line from points or a graph
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Find the midpoint of a line segment
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Find the coordinates of a point rotated 180º around a given center point
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Use relationships involving area, perimeter, and volume of geometric figures to compute another measure (e.g., surface area for a cube of a given volume and simple geometric probability)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Use the Pythagorean theorem
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Apply properties of 30º-60º-90º, 45º-45º-90º, similar, and congruent triangles
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Apply basic trigonometric ratios to solve right-triangle problems
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Use the distance formula
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Use properties of parallel and perpendicular lines to determine an equation of a line or coordinates of a point
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Find the coordinates of a point reflected across a vertical or horizontal line or across y = x
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Find the coordinates of a point rotated 90º about the origin
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Recognize special characteristics of parabolas and circles (e.g., the vertex of a parabola and the center or radius of a circle)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Use relationships among angles, arcs, and distances in a circle
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Compute the area of composite geometric figures when planning and/or visualization is required
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Use scale factors to determine the magnitude of a size change
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Analyze and draw conclusions based on a set of conditions
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve multistep geometry problems that involve integrating concepts, planning, and/or visualization
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve problems in one or two steps using whole numbers and using decimals in the context of money
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Exhibit knowledge of basic expressions (e.g., identify an expression for a total as b + g)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Extend a given pattern by a few terms for patterns that have a constant increase or decrease between terms
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve equations in the form x + a = b, where a and b are whole numbers or decimals
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve routine one-step arithmetic problems using positive rational numbers, such as single-step percent
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve some routine two-step arithmetic problems
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Relate a graph to a situation described qualitatively in terms of familiar properties such as before and after, increasing and decreasing, higher and lower
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Apply a definition of an operation for whole numbers (e.g., a ◘ b = 3a – b)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Substitute whole numbers for unknown quantities to evaluate expressions
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Extend a given pattern by a few terms for patterns that have a constant factor between terms
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve one-step equations to get integer or decimal answers
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Combine like terms (e.g., 2x + 5x)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve routine two-step or three-step arithmetic problems involving concepts such as rate and proportion, tax added, percentage off, and estimating by using a given average value in place of actual values
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Perform straightforward word-to-symbol translations
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Relate a graph to a situation described in terms of a starting value and an additional amount per unit (e.g., unit cost, weekly growth)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Evaluate algebraic expressions by substituting integers for unknown quantities
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Evaluate linear and quadratic functions, expressed in function notation, at integer values
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Add and subtract simple algebraic expressions
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve routine first-degree equations
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Multiply two binomials
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Match simple inequalities with their graphs on the number line (e.g., x ≥ –3/5)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Exhibit knowledge of slope
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve multistep arithmetic problems that involve planning or converting common derived units of measure (e.g., feet per second to miles per hour)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Build functions and write expressions, equations, or inequalities with a single variable for common pre-algebra settings (e.g., rate and distance problems and problems that can be solved by using proportions)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Match linear equations with their graphs in the coordinate plane
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Recognize that when numerical quantities are reported in real-world contexts, the numbers are often rounded
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve real-world problems by using first-degree equations
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve first-degree inequalities when the method does not involve reversing the inequality sign
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Match compound inequalities with their graphs on the number line (e.g., –10.5 < x <= 20.3)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Add, subtract, and multiply polynomials
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Identify solutions to simple quadratic equations
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve quadratic equations in the form (x + a)(x + b) = 0, where a and b are numbers or variables
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Factor simple quadratics (e.g., the difference of squares and perfect square trinomials)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Work with squares and square roots of numbers
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Work with cubes and cube roots of numbers
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Work with scientific notation
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Work problems involving positive integer exponents
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Determine when an expression is undefined
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Determine the slope of a line from an equation
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Evaluate polynomial functions, expressed in function notation, at integer values
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Find the next term in a sequence described recursively
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Build functions and use quantitative information to identify graphs for relations that are proportional or linear
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Attend to the difference between a function modeling a situation and the reality of the situation
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Understand the concept of a function as having a well-defined output value at each valid input value
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Understand the concept of domain and range in terms of valid input and output, and in terms of function graphs
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Interpret statements that use function notation in terms of their context
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Find the domain of polynomial functions and rational functions
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Find the range of polynomial functions
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Find where a rational function's graph has a vertical asymptote
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Use function notation for simple functions of two variables
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve word problems containing several rates, proportions, or percentages
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Build functions and write expressions, equations, and inequalities for common algebra settings (e.g., distance to a point on a curve and profit for variable cost and demand)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Interpret and use information from graphs in the coordinate plane
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Given an equation or function, find an equation or function whose graph is a translation by a specified amount up or down
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Manipulate expressions and equations
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve linear inequalities when the method involves reversing the inequality sign
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Match linear inequalities with their graphs on the number line
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve systems of two linear equations
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve quadratic equations
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve absolute value equations
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Relate a graph to a situation described qualitatively in terms of faster change or slower change
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Build functions for relations that are inversely proportional
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Find a recursive expression for the general term in a sequence described recursively
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Evaluate composite functions at integer values
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve complex arithmetic problems involving percent of increase or decrease or requiring integration of several concepts (e.g., using several ratios, comparing percentages, or comparing averages)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Build functions and write expressions, equations, and inequalities when the process requires planning and/or strategic manipulation
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Analyze and draw conclusions based on properties of algebra and/or functions
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Analyze and draw conclusions based on information from graphs in the coordinate plane
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Identify characteristics of graphs based on a set of conditions or on a general equation such as y = ax<sup>2</sup> + c
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Given an equation or function, find an equation or function whose graph is a translation by specified amounts in the horizontal and vertical directions
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Solve simple absolute value inequalities
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Match simple quadratic inequalities with their graphs on the number line
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Apply the remainder theorem for polynomials, that P(a) is the remainder when P(x) is divided by (x – a)
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Compare actual values and the values of a modeling function to judge model fit and compare models
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Build functions for relations that are exponential
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Exhibit knowledge of geometric sequences
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Exhibit knowledge of unit circle trigonometry
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Match graphs of basic trigonometric functions with their equations
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Use trigonometric concepts and basic identities to solve problems
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Exhibit knowledge of logarithms
Statement.subject: Mathematics

Statement.name: Write an expression for the composite of two simple functions
Statement.subject: Mathematics
